THE CHURCH YARD.

How should the hours OF the Sabbath, tAat
ar. not occupied by public worship. be spent!
This question is often asked The answer
te it must depend in some degree on tne
circun stances of the person by whom II is
made. 1t is easy to say in general terms that
the day should not be spent IN indoience-
nor sloth-nor worldly pleasure, but that u
should be devoted to personal and SOCIAL
Improvement. The methots best suited 70
accomplish this end will vary with indlvla-
al situation. Domestic instruction should
be especially regarded on the Sabbath, when
children are released from the exercises OF
school, and parents have opportunities OF
reaching their minds, which their own en-
gagements during the week may perhaps
confne to this season. Charitable sevlces
are appropriate to the day Visiting the
moor and the sick, is an Office to which
portion of the Sabbath may be given with
peculiar benefit. Sunday Schools require,
the attendance Of considerable number oi
serious persons, and we know no class OF
Christians who are entitled to higher com
mendation, than they who are willing to
foreeo the pleasures of private meditation and
reading, that they may give religious IN,
struction to the children of the Ignorant and
vicious. Few persons will find it profitable
to spend the whole day in seclusion; 1t was
not meant to be day of unnatural re-
straint. Few also, from their habits, can
derive pleasure from long continued exer-
else of reading. Useful conversation should
be NEUTRALITY-SUSPICIOUS. in its tone, but easy
and interesting, and having, as much as pos
sble, direct Influence on the religious char'
acter. Sunday is not a day for fasting. but
neither is it day for feasting. we sus'
pend our usual pursuits, but it is not sea
son for idleness to waste, nor for levity tt
profane. 1t should be so employed that vt
may be better and happier for it through
the week.

1T is fact my friend, worth recording,
that in all the public institutions formed in
France, by Napoleon, for the education OF
the daughters of those who fell in the SER
vice of their country, the duty OF the house
formed principal part ot their tuition
They were taught'with care writing, arith-
metic, AID keeping house or expense books;
mantua makers, women faiiors, and MILL
ners, were employed in teaching them how
to cut out and make up cvepy species OF gar
ment. and they took turns in groups of half
dozen from each class 10 assist experience
ed cooks in the kitchen of the establish
ments. where they were taught the art of
cooking, the price and qualities ofprovisions,
and to maM pastry jellies, &c. In short ev-
eyy branch of household industry was at
tended to. while reading the best authors,
music. drawing, embroidery and dancing oc-
cuped a portion of their time. In part OF
| Germany, ] found this system OF education
for women had beenpursued tor many years.
In Switzerland it is the same on smaller
scale. How many women DO we see III thc
commercial society d France, Germany and
Switzerland, taking charge occasionally OF
their husbands affairs, attending to his
books, CARRYING on his correspondence, and,
| in case of his death, continuing the business
Of his house with success.

POMpEY'S STATUE,
Az whose pedestal julius Cesar fell, is still pre-
served in the Palazzo Spada, al Rome
Cold and inanimate! Would thou could'st ope
Thy marble lips, and tell what thou hast seen
Upon the ides of March! thou, at whose feet
Yell the worlds mouarch eloquent and brave,
The great in conquest, and the proud of soul.
Wak;d there no spark Promethian in thy breast,
When sadly mufTed in Lis mantle's fold,

nascss ~ .n ;mpa,ient sword; and the keen point
of Cassi,,s. and the s'unsndest cut {. e!f'

of traitorous taggers search'd that noble breast,

Had seen bright clad in victory's bdrnish d mall

Tragic close
of mad ambitions drama!-the deep plant
of"Et tn Brute! e!'-and the indignant pang
with which that proud soul left the wounded


clay,
OF friendship and Of faith!


And yet that world
Had owed HIM little, save the blood that made
Her harvests plenteous, save the unheeded groan
of famish'd widow, and OF sireless babe,
A meteor glory kindled up at Rome,
And all besides desert, Deeds like these,
How weigh they in heavens balance, when the


pomp

hand

ers,

pOMpEY'S STATUE,

Know ye the land on whose wood-covered meun-


tain


All nature in grandeur and glory is seen!
Where the song Of the wood.thrush is heard by


the fountain,
And wild-roses bloom on the emerald greenf
Know We the land where the forests of pine
Spread darkly their shades to the sunbeams that


shine -,
Where the cataract's waves through the Wild
woods resound,
And the Prairie in rghtness and beauty is found
Whose streams are most mighty that roll TO the
main-
Whose woods are the deepest that wave on the


plain
KNOW YE THE LAND!

With roses red and lilies pale,


come thv narrow couch to strew
II is not meet that things so frail


As flowers should longer bloom than you.
But Yesterday thou casp'd my hand,
And now beside thy grave stand.
Not if the silver moon had drop'd,


Mid all her glory, down from heaven;
Not if the rolling stars had stop'd


Their mighty march, would they have given
Unto my heart such wild surprise,


As when saw Death seal thine eyes.
Those eyes those living orbs of blue,


Where burned the holy fire of love-
That a celestial lustre drew


From inward thoughts of scenes above,
Earth's glittering curtain-how could they
So sweetly beam, then fade away
Who would have dream'd, who heard thy tongue


Its streams of vital music pour
Upon the soul, that thou, who sung


So angel-like, wouldst sing no more
Yet those same lips that once could warble,
Are cold and silent, now, as marble.
Maiden, call thee! oh, awake!


And from thy spotless shroud of snow
Let one soft whisper spirit break,
To tell thou'rt happy there b. below e. I.srn
OF thy calm slumbers in the urn.
For one who was, in life, so fair


As thou-so innocent Of breath,
Surely golden gown must wear,


Among pale shadows, after death;
And shine, bright youths and beauty's queen,
As thou on earth before hadst been.
Like as the sunbeam paints the cloud,


At eve, so ditlst thou gild my heart;
Like as the sunbeam leaves that cloud


In darkness, so didst thou depart.
Would had wings to follow thee,
Since thou no more wilt come to me.
Greenly the grass DER thee shall wave,
Greenly shall droop the hanging willow,
Birds, to chant drges DER thy grave
Shall cross, each summer, the blue billow,
And blade, and leaf, and bird shall share
Lfc's gift, while thou art mouldering there!
STANZAS.

The morning of that costly pageant, the
bridal of the Adriatic. had arrived-the
dark canals of Venice were deserted, and
the whole population of the city were gid-
ing over the sea. The ocean breezes were
soft and refreshing. The banners of the gon-
dolas fluttered gaily in the air. and all was
blithe and beautiful. Near the state-vesselS
of the Dogc, f1oated the barge ofthe Duke
de Faurni, but the eye of the multitude was
not turned to him: his daughter-the last re-
naming prop of his house-thc beautiful
Rosine-the bright flower of the Republi.
can States--occupied the attention of those
around her.


Rosline was. at this period, entering her
eighteenth year-the time when the females
Of the south yossess that peculiar beauty.
which unitps The vivid loveliness of youth
with the matirer grace of womanhood; hers
were the true Italian embellishments: the
vermllion lps--the clear brown cheek, over
which the damask tinge rested--the dark
flashing ewes, bespeaking heart formed for
devoted love, mingled with an enchanting
maiden delicacy. to which often the Vcne-
tian females are stmngers-these were the
few gems of worth The observer could at Fl st
discover; the renainder g'ittered in the
souls casket. But Rosline's love-her first
love--and what love is so fervent as that ot
ycuth9 was given; and the hearts affection
of one, whose VOWS were to her the world
alone she could breathe, she received. Who
then wondered that the beautiful girl gazed
not ON the scene before her--that the mu-
sic's strain was unheard-and the showy
spectacle was to her insipid' Surely no one;
the man who p5sses ssed her love was by her
side--and in his presence, the worlds pleas
ure and the ciy's gaiety we're tasteless.-


The Youngest son of noble British family,
possessed of hikh personal and mental beau
tv, the inheritdr of relatives princcly for
tune, aspred t, the hand Of Rosline, and
became her accepted lover-her betrothed
husband


On the sparkling bosom of the sea there
now re'gned an unbrokcn silence; the Doge
pronounced the well known sentences, and
| the glittering ring fell; then the loud clar-


ions, mingled with the shout of countless


voices. Iynt the air the asse mbled gondolas
dispersed, and the living tide once more en-
tered the CITY. Tie vows of attachment
tho hurried accents ,fthe glishman-were


again listened to. and prolonged-until the
rilded bark arrived at the marble steps OF


the Dukes palace.


The entertainment given that evening by


the Duke exceeded, in splendour and mag


niicence, the banquet of the Doge on the


preceding morning. But amid the beautiful


and noble females who graced the mansion,


Rosline shonc conspicuous; wandering with


her lover through the long colonades, IN


which dim twilight reigned; or. encircled


bv his arm, and minglng in the festive
|dance, she was alike an earthly Paraalse.---


But. alas, it was doomed to be transient,
ileeting, and decaving'

hour of morning ere the guests departed;-
Steinford pressed the lips of Rosline once
more. and repeated the heightened adieu-
ever and anon castinga lingering glance as
she crossed the corridor to her apartments

from his brother in it he SAID their father
Law on his death bed, and desired to see hi


i.st horn before life was ended; the lette'

With the speed of lightning. he placed
; the nacket in his bosom, and strobe across

surprised at his vehemence. His frantic e.

'Tis sad history:--The maid was slain
by one who was her lover

You must think me silly; but when child
these words sank deep into my breast.---
Now to rest, Henry-I will prepare your

hnt the separation did not apnear tc- -

"Surely, surely, dearest" was the reply;
81 promise you--your' father, Rosine-A
must see him ere / depart. Oncemore fare
and again-then left her: no sigh, no cry OF
agony burst from the lips of Rosline; the
door closed. and he was gone.


The travels of one in haste to regain his
native land, are generally void of interest;
so it was with Steinford's; his journey exhib-
tied little variety, and he arrived at the cas-
tie of his father in safety, but too late. The
last sigh of his parent had been breathed-
the last PRAYER for his welfare had been
offered up-aud the senseless form was Lard
in its narrow bed, there to meet corruption.
The dreadful uncertainty, the feverish i'm


patience Of him who hopes the best, yet


breads to hear the confirmation OF his fears,


generally produces intense grief, when the
fatal truth is known. Henry's sorrow was
therefore deep, though unavailing, and he
ask ed if happiness would ever more belong
to hin his heart at that moment answer
ed, No.--But what does not time accomplish!
The keen edge of affliction is destroyeds
the mostened eye is dried; and the wounded
heart is healed. Thus, then, it is through
life. When the bosom is surcharged with
misery. it is then obdurate to the voice o
comfort; let few months pass, and he who
had before turned away, will listen with a.


viditv. So it was with Steinford: the young


recluse again mingled in society, and the
laugh of gaiety again played upon ms ilps. :.


And where nov was Rosline! Truly. 1t


must be said if she was thought Of, it was


casually:-if her devoted attachment was


remembered, it was only as a pleasant


dream-a delightful vison--from which the


sleeper awoke to dread realities.
| But what had caused this change! Whar
had turned Steinford's affections from one


,o whom he had sworn everlasting allegiances
one. in whose breast he would never, ne


yer be forgotten? The world had caused IT,


The voice of nattery had been poured IN


the ear of the rich and handsome Steinfordi


the eve Of an English maiden had beamed OH
him-and Roslne was forgotten.


i II ;s not that the heart of man IS unform-


ed to centre it's affections on one object, anu
that one alone; but it is the desire. the pro"


nppsity. If | may so term it, of lettering the
i Affections OF many---ofi leading crowds IN hlS


chains: dealing life or death, by smiles os
frowns.

Il really want to get married, and have

instead of these beautiful domestic crea-
lures our country abounded with, whose
home was their delight. who made their
ozvn, and their children's clothes, who at
tended to the domestic affairs OF the house
by assisting in all its concerns, find set OF
giggling, gossipping trifiers. in whose minds
balls, plays, carriages and novels are upper
most; the kitchen they~never enter, they
hardly know head of ofcabbage from head
of lettuce; or leg of mutton from shoul-
der. though they are great connolssenrs in
Ice creams, and as to mending pair ol
breeches for brother or husband. they
would cry 6c upon you or faint were you te

while these same fashionables will set {
whole evening without blush to hear one
of Shakespeare obscene plays-music, deal

full articles.headline:
THE MDTE1TOR.

THE CHURCH YARD.
full articles.article:
You have sauntered, perhaps, of moon
Ii ght evening out of the precincts or thc NV
ing. moving world, to inger and contem
plate among the grass grown memorials OF
those who are gone--


trhe body to lis place, and the soul to heavens


grace,


And the rest in Gods own time"


An appalling chill shoots through the cur
rents of life, at the undisturbed and univer-
sal silence of the scene---the stars tfanquiliy
shining on the white marble. and ireely lilu
minating the name, which trlehdshiP hid
carved for the slumbercr beneath; here tne
grass waving IN rank luXuriance, as II 10 moe
the triumphs and the trophies OF oeasp, ana
there human bone unearthed from its time
worn sepuchrc, ghasty visitor 10 tne
REALMS of day; a wooden tablet, marking the
renosc Of the humble; cross, the sign OF the
believer. and lofty and magnificent memo
,ials over the mortal relics of the wealthy
and The great. An who in such an assem-
blare as this, can be accounted great -
What gold survives the crucible OF death.
{Na c,s learn nothing from the living
,,h;ch the dead do not teach US, W ou'd
hean,v he modest and unpretcndlng, let hcf
o,;t the hall and the festival for moment,
and carry her toilet to the tomb. Wouio
the nroud learn humility; the pcnurieus
charity. the frivolous seriousness; the D'got-
ed phitanthropy; would the scholar ascer.
tain the true objects of knowledge; the man
of the world the true means OF happiness
here and hereafter; and the ambitious, the
true sources of greatness; let him retire "A
while from the living and commune with tne
dead. We must all come to the mourniul
and silent grave. Our bones must minge ~
one common mass. Our affections should
travel in the same path, for they must ter
inmate in one fearful issue Lite IS tuli OF
facilities of virtue and happiness; and wneh
YOU would abuse them, 30 purity your aHec-
tions, and humble your pride. and leave
your hopes at the tomb OF a friend, whe" '
The stars are shining upon it like the giorl-,
Gus beams of religion on the mansion oi
death.

full articles.headline: rEE SABEATE.
full articles.article:
How should the hours OF the Sabbath, tAat
ar. not occupied by public worship. be spent!
This question is often asked The answer
te it must depend in some degree on tne
circun stances of the person by whom II is
made. 1t is easy to say in general terms that
the day should not be spent IN indoience-
nor sloth-nor worldly pleasure, but that u
should be devoted to personal and SOCIAL
Improvement. The methots best suited 70
accomplish this end will vary with indlvla-
al situation. Domestic instruction should
be especially regarded on the Sabbath, when
children are released from the exercises OF
school, and parents have opportunities OF
reaching their minds, which their own en-
gagements during the week may perhaps
confne to this season. Charitable sevlces
are appropriate to the day Visiting the
moor and the sick, is an Office to which
portion of the Sabbath may be given with
peculiar benefit. Sunday Schools require,
the attendance Of considerable number oi
serious persons, and we know no class OF
Christians who are entitled to higher com
mendation, than they who are willing to
foreeo the pleasures of private meditation and
reading, that they may give religious IN,
struction to the children of the Ignorant and
vicious. Few persons will find it profitable
to spend the whole day in seclusion; 1t was
not meant to be day of unnatural re-
straint. Few also, from their habits, can
derive pleasure from long continued exer-
else of reading. Useful conversation should
be NEUTRALITY-SUSPICIOUS. in its tone, but easy
and interesting, and having, as much as pos
sble, direct Influence on the religious char'
acter. Sunday is not a day for fasting. but
neither is it day for feasting. we sus'
pend our usual pursuits, but it is not sea
son for idleness to waste, nor for levity tt
profane. 1t should be so employed that vt
may be better and happier for it through
the week.

full articles.article:
The Greenlanders never salute one another;
they cannot without laughter, advert to the no
ton of ono person being Inferior to another, :,


The islanders in the ncThborhood OF the Ph'i-
ipines lay hold of the hatd or foot OF the person
whom they accost, and rub their faces with 1t.


The Laplanders press the nose strongly against
that of the individual they are salutinS


In New Guinea they Place leaves on the head
of the person saluted.


In the Straits of Sunl,, the foot OF the person
saluted is raised, and pissed gently along the
right leg, and over the body.
The inhabitants of the PHILIPPINE Isles bend We
ry low, with their hands on their cheeks anu
| with one of the feet raised in the air, and knee
bent.
| The Ethiopian takes lis friends garment and
| binds it round hmselfin such way as to leave
the former naked.


| In saluting, the Japanese takes oil one shoe,
and the people of Aracan Their sandais, ~hen III
the street: in the house they take off their bree
ches.


Black Kings ofthc Coast Of Africa, salute eaGh
other by squeezing three several times each o'h-
er's middle finger.
peculiar attachment open vein, and present 10
their friend the blood that springs forth to drink.


when the Chinese meet their acquaintance AZ
ter long separation, they cast themselves on
their knees, incline their heads towards the
ground two or three times, and put IN pracsice'

have. besides. a kind of ritual or academy OF
complishments, where number OF revere"ces
and gcnutlc xions, and the word suitable 10 each'
are regularly laid down. Ambassadors repea.
these ceremonies forty days before appearing AZ
Court.


The Otahctians cock their noses at cach other'

are, The latter form is derived, undoubtedly

one was a navigator and fisher. >,

YOU carry yourself" of the second is eqnany es

, In Africa, young betrothed damsel puts 4,
, little water into calabash, and kneehng uy ~

= in it; the girl then weeping, with pleasure drih'


the water This is looked on Us the grea'e

And grandest the lake On its bosom tht lies
And highest the hills that above them aisc,-
Where ludest the rocks that hang overme shore'
And d, epest the cave by the wild wate's roar
Where the wonders of art as by magic I'pear,
And give new charm to the wilderness here
Where the city and village are seen in is shade'
And the plpughnan is found in the grass cover


ed gladel


wave,


The home of the frec,-and the cline of the


brave.

d ,ghtful music, only studied to shew fine
ar n and hand, or a highly amended piano,
no. string of which is ever toned to please
a father or husband, who are consider
cd heavy old fashioned pieces of furniture,
mere lumber about the house-dfzvayS IN the
7pdy.


1T is fact my friend, worth recording,
that in all the public institutions formed in
France, by Napoleon, for the education OF
the daughters of those who fell in the SER
vice of their country, the duty OF the house
formed principal part ot their tuition
They were taught'with care writing, arith-
metic, AID keeping house or expense books;
mantua makers, women faiiors, and MILL
ners, were employed in teaching them how
to cut out and make up cvepy species OF gar
ment. and they took turns in groups of half
dozen from each class 10 assist experience
ed cooks in the kitchen of the establish
ments. where they were taught the art of
cooking, the price and qualities ofprovisions,
and to maM pastry jellies, &c. In short ev-
eyy branch of household industry was at
tended to. while reading the best authors,
music. drawing, embroidery and dancing oc-
cuped a portion of their time. In part OF
| Germany, ] found this system OF education
for women had beenpursued tor many years.
In Switzerland it is the same on smaller
scale. How many women DO we see III thc
commercial society d France, Germany and
Switzerland, taking charge occasionally OF
their husbands affairs, attending to his
books, CARRYING on his correspondence, and,
| in case of his death, continuing the business
Of his house with success.


with us these things are too much neg
| lectetl, to dress and parade the streets IN kld
or white satin shoes, irrayed in all the CO.
ors of the rainbow, ts dash, married or sln-
gle, in splendid equipagc in English style
that's YOUR Sort talk loud in company, osle
dandy, shun the old and experienced, and
harrass servants for their petty wants, and
their husbands and fathers, for what they
cannot afford to give hem; money to sup
mort them IN their extravaganza, appears 10
be the sole occupation of the females IN what
lis called the Fashionable circles IN our below
cd country. My hcaM sckens on contem-
plating such things. Away with these non
descripts may they all die old maids, and
waste their sourncss Qor sweetness they
have not) On the desert air,--men OF dis-
cerDment will seek the modest. discreet, re.
tiring female, who will prove crown OF
glory to her husband


/ Sweet AS the rose


When the dew-drop vets its leaves,
Untantcd and pure


As the lily Of the mountains SNOW


"When find such a one, will change my
forlorn condition; and, lyon undertake tc
choose her for me, promise you as tar as
relates to me, she shall pass her time,


sCaim and unrufied as summers sea-


When not breath of wind blows DER its surface.

full articles.headline:
From The Ep;scopai Hatchman.
pOMpEY'S STATUE,
full articles.article:
From me EpScopM VatchWdh'


POMpEY'S STATUE,
Az whose pedestal julius Cesar fell, is still pre-
served in the Palazzo Spada, al Rome
Cold and inanimate! Would thou could'st ope
Thy marble lips, and tell what thou hast seen
Upon the ides of March! thou, at whose feet
Yell the worlds mouarch eloquent and brave,
The great in conquest, and the proud of soul.
Wak;d there no spark Promethian in thy breast,
When sadly mufTed in Lis mantle's fold,
Painting he sank on tltee


Didst thou stand fotrh
,I...,se dark and motionless beauty, while
nascss ~ .n ;mpa,ient sword; and the keen point
of Cassi,,s. and the s'unsndest cut {. e!f'
FROM the loved hand of rutus, and the rage
of traitorous taggers search'd that noble breast,
Which Gaul and Egypt, and Pharsallas PLAINS
Had seen bright clad in victory's bdrnish d mall
Trembling as at war-godf


Tragic close
of mad ambitions drama!-the deep plant
of"Et tn Brute! e!'-and the indignant pang
with which that proud soul left the wounded


clay,
OF friendship and Of faith!


And yet that world
Had owed HIM little, save the blood that made
Her harvests plenteous, save the unheeded groan
of famish'd widow, and OF sireless babe,
A meteor glory kindled up at Rome,
And all besides desert, Deeds like these,
How weigh they in heavens balance, when the


pomp


Of earth had Aed away, Nun may mott Judge.
But wait in trembling for his trial-day.
And yet 'twould seem that the meek hind whose


hand


Made hard with labor, deals the daily bread
TO the young nurslings of his humble nest,
Whose head beneath his planted trees and How


ers,


Sinks calmly down in the long sleep OF death,
Hath better passport to the cline Of peace,
Than the blood nourishd master OF a world.

full articles.headline: KNOW YE THE LAND!
full articles.article:
Know ye the land on whose wood-covered meun-


tain


All nature in grandeur and glory is seen!
Where the song Of the wood.thrush is heard by


the fountain,
And wild-roses bloom on the emerald greenf
Know We the land where the forests of pine
Spread darkly their shades to the sunbeams that


shine -,
Where the cataract's waves through the Wild
woods resound,
And the Prairie in rghtness and beauty is found
Whose streams are most mighty that roll TO the
main-
Whose woods are the deepest that wave on the


plain

full articles.headline: STANZAS.
full articles.article:
With roses red and lilies pale,


come thv narrow couch to strew
II is not meet that things so frail


As flowers should longer bloom than you.
But Yesterday thou casp'd my hand,
And now beside thy grave stand.
Not if the silver moon had drop'd,


Mid all her glory, down from heaven;
Not if the rolling stars had stop'd


Their mighty march, would they have given
Unto my heart such wild surprise,


As when saw Death seal thine eyes.
Those eyes those living orbs of blue,


Where burned the holy fire of love-
That a celestial lustre drew


From inward thoughts of scenes above,
Earth's glittering curtain-how could they
So sweetly beam, then fade away
Who would have dream'd, who heard thy tongue


Its streams of vital music pour
Upon the soul, that thou, who sung


So angel-like, wouldst sing no more
Yet those same lips that once could warble,
Are cold and silent, now, as marble.
Maiden, call thee! oh, awake!


And from thy spotless shroud of snow
Let one soft whisper spirit break,
To tell thou'rt happy there b. below e. I.srn
OF thy calm slumbers in the urn.
For one who was, in life, so fair


As thou-so innocent Of breath,
Surely golden gown must wear,


Among pale shadows, after death;
And shine, bright youths and beauty's queen,
As thou on earth before hadst been.
Like as the sunbeam paints the cloud,


At eve, so ditlst thou gild my heart;
Like as the sunbeam leaves that cloud


In darkness, so didst thou depart.
Would had wings to follow thee,
Since thou no more wilt come to me.
Greenly the grass DER thee shall wave,
Greenly shall droop the hanging willow,
Birds, to chant drges DER thy grave
Shall cross, each summer, the blue billow,
And blade, and leaf, and bird shall share
Lfc's gift, while thou art mouldering there!

full articles.headline:
THE CONSTANT VENETIAN.

'Tis sad history:--The maid was slain
by one who was her lover
full articles.article:
The morning of that costly pageant, the
bridal of the Adriatic. had arrived-the
dark canals of Venice were deserted, and
the whole population of the city were gid-
ing over the sea. The ocean breezes were
soft and refreshing. The banners of the gon-
dolas fluttered gaily in the air. and all was
blithe and beautiful. Near the state-vesselS
of the Dogc, f1oated the barge ofthe Duke
de Faurni, but the eye of the multitude was
not turned to him: his daughter-the last re-
naming prop of his house-thc beautiful
Rosine-the bright flower of the Republi.
can States--occupied the attention of those
around her.


Rosline was. at this period, entering her
eighteenth year-the time when the females
Of the south yossess that peculiar beauty.
which unitps The vivid loveliness of youth
with the matirer grace of womanhood; hers
were the true Italian embellishments: the
vermllion lps--the clear brown cheek, over
which the damask tinge rested--the dark
flashing ewes, bespeaking heart formed for
devoted love, mingled with an enchanting
maiden delicacy. to which often the Vcne-
tian females are stmngers-these were the
few gems of worth The observer could at Fl st
discover; the renainder g'ittered in the
souls casket. But Rosline's love-her first
love--and what love is so fervent as that ot
ycuth9 was given; and the hearts affection
of one, whose VOWS were to her the world
alone she could breathe, she received. Who
then wondered that the beautiful girl gazed
not ON the scene before her--that the mu-
sic's strain was unheard-and the showy
spectacle was to her insipid' Surely no one;
the man who p5sses ssed her love was by her
side--and in his presence, the worlds pleas
ure and the ciy's gaiety we're tasteless.-


The Youngest son of noble British family,
possessed of hikh personal and mental beau
tv, the inheritdr of relatives princcly for
tune, aspred t, the hand Of Rosline, and
became her accepted lover-her betrothed
husband


On the sparkling bosom of the sea there
now re'gned an unbrokcn silence; the Doge
pronounced the well known sentences, and
| the glittering ring fell; then the loud clar-


ions, mingled with the shout of countless


voices. Iynt the air the asse mbled gondolas
dispersed, and the living tide once more en-
tered the CITY. Tie vows of attachment
tho hurried accents ,fthe glishman-were


again listened to. and prolonged-until the
rilded bark arrived at the marble steps OF


the Dukes palace.


The entertainment given that evening by


the Duke exceeded, in splendour and mag


niicence, the banquet of the Doge on the


preceding morning. But amid the beautiful


and noble females who graced the mansion,


Rosline shonc conspicuous; wandering with


her lover through the long colonades, IN


which dim twilight reigned; or. encircled


bv his arm, and minglng in the festive
|dance, she was alike an earthly Paraalse.---


But. alas, it was doomed to be transient,
ileeting, and decaving'


The clock of St. Mark tolled the third
hour of morning ere the guests departed;-
Steinford pressed the lips of Rosline once
more. and repeated the heightened adieu-
ever and anon castinga lingering glance as
she crossed the corridor to her apartments


tt was at that moment messenger arriv-


ed at the palace, bearing letter tor tine


Enrlishman, which he said required his I'M
mediate perusal; it was from his native Isle
from his brother in it he SAID their father
Law on his death bed, and desired to see hi


i.st horn before life was ended; the lette'
. concluded with an earnest WISH TOT oteih
ford's instant return to England.


With the speed of lightning. he placed
; the nacket in his bosom, and strobe across
the gallery, leaving the courier alone, ant


surprised at his vehemence. His frantic e.
nunciation of their parting excited deep ter


ror IN the breast of Roslinc, as he entered


her apartment. No lamp burned in th'
, room. and the faint rosy tinge which gleam
) ed in the east threw pleasing light on thu
snowy pillars and silken draperies.


"Dearest Rosline, we must part" lie re
a peatetl in trembling tone; "but wili re
turn again."


, "Never-never," said Rosline, in lo'
Y whisper; Steintord, know full well tn
character of you northern men; here,
hold YOU in a silken cham Z; there, ITS ink
!, will seyer-absence anuuls the strongest tt
= Of love-"


"Rosline, dearest Rosline," he returned
). elf YOU value my future peace OF mind, tai
a not in such strain. Can you distrust my at
= tachment?''-and he pressed her to nj
k heart as he spoke-'may you be avenged
= l forsake you Sweet one' doubt not m
TRUTH
y "Henry," exclaimed Rosline, disengag'n


herself from his embrace, "the Origins
= Of this" (and she drew from her bosom n
'i picture) "shall never cease to occupy m


heart"
e 81 swear by the bright beams OF that m
Y ing sun, that life itself shall tail to anlma
u u my frame, before my love for thee shall
st quenched." :.
a ,o "Holy Nary she continued, bending b.
:. fore the image Of the virgin; "reglster, II
,s vow. And now Stemford," she added, "ioe
II. on this scene once again; morning has crin


soned the oceM, and the fresh air waves u


lo,rY,e .n the halcOny. WEcn

You must think me silly; but when child
these words sank deep into my breast.---
Now to rest, Henry-I will prepare your
repast before you leave me, e,"-and she bent
her head to hide the warm tears, which fell
rapidly.


"There will be no rest this day far me-"
said Steinford; in an hour shall be on
my road; therefore, my farewell must be
brief"


"Ro slime, you will see me again at Venice


-then," he added in fond whisper. 1--WE
part no more"


hnt the separation did not apnear tc- -
eager tone, IAN hoar,y yi,dss Saf tho's says Wilt
thou promise me to remain one hour longer
hcre?"


"Surely, surely, dearest" was the reply;
81 promise you--your' father, Rosine-A
must see him ere / depart. Oncemore fare
and again-then left her: no sigh, no cry OF
agony burst from the lips of Rosline; the
door closed. and he was gone.


The travels of one in haste to regain his
native land, are generally void of interest;
so it was with Steinford's; his journey exhib-
tied little variety, and he arrived at the cas-
tie of his father in safety, but too late. The
last sigh of his parent had been breathed-
the last PRAYER for his welfare had been
offered up-aud the senseless form was Lard
in its narrow bed, there to meet corruption.
The dreadful uncertainty, the feverish i'm


patience Of him who hopes the best, yet


breads to hear the confirmation OF his fears,


generally produces intense grief, when the
fatal truth is known. Henry's sorrow was
therefore deep, though unavailing, and he
ask ed if happiness would ever more belong
to hin his heart at that moment answer
ed, No.--But what does not time accomplish!
The keen edge of affliction is destroyeds
the mostened eye is dried; and the wounded
heart is healed. Thus, then, it is through
life. When the bosom is surcharged with
misery. it is then obdurate to the voice o
comfort; let few months pass, and he who
had before turned away, will listen with a.


viditv. So it was with Steinford: the young


recluse again mingled in society, and the
laugh of gaiety again played upon ms ilps. :.


And where nov was Rosline! Truly. 1t


must be said if she was thought Of, it was


casually:-if her devoted attachment was


remembered, it was only as a pleasant


dream-a delightful vison--from which the


sleeper awoke to dread realities.
| But what had caused this change! Whar
had turned Steinford's affections from one


,o whom he had sworn everlasting allegiances
one. in whose breast he would never, ne


yer be forgotten? The world had caused IT,


The voice of nattery had been poured IN


the ear of the rich and handsome Steinfordi


the eve Of an English maiden had beamed OH
him-and Roslne was forgotten.


i II ;s not that the heart of man IS unform-


ed to centre it's affections on one object, anu
that one alone; but it is the desire. the pro"


nppsity. If | may so term it, of lettering the
i Affections OF many---ofi leading crowds IN hlS


chains: dealing life or death, by smiles os
frowns.
H During this time the conscience OF Henry


did not slumber-and, when it reproacheo
him. he would mingle in the dissipations OK
. IN. city. and speed to the haunts OF the
profigate. A Soung Italian had constantly
, attended him, whether it was to the courtiy
: feast, or noisy revel; though It was eviaeht
$ he was i'll at ease in Britain. Ihose VINO ie-
r earded the evident melancholy OF the Ooy:
would fain have persuaded Steinford to send


hin, sea;n to his native land: no feeling of
pity nstgated them; they liked not the
S presence Of "the familiar" as he was term
| ed; at their nightly orgies his scorntul smile
told of his contempt, and again his tearful
eve spoke of sorrow for his master.
/ One night, one eventful night, when, after
e crowded ball, Henry conducted lady, to
: whom il was said he was to be united, to her
e eouipaye. he motioned the Italian to aP-


proach: "Thy lady's carriage" he exclaim-
: ed; "seek for it Julio thou must haVe mn
: for thy page,"he continued. addressing ms


companion but the boy started forward;
' "Nay, nay. it cannot be-" he remarKeo'
c TREMENDOUSLY, ~ am no hireling to be trans
] ferred at pleasure" and the deep flush or
S his hitherto pallid cheek bespoke his deter
e minaton. :


"Back, back. boy" said Stein.ord IN
tone Of anger, thrusting him aside; "you ar'
/ unmindful of your station"
:. AS he spoke, the countenance OF JUNO al.
i tered: the crimson blood waxed faint; ths
If flashing eve beamed not; the curled up pe'
v came still-he would have spoken--ou.
with half suppressed sigh he turned away
: "ris a strange boy" again Steinford;
Is met him at post-house near Venice wners
y he told me iamen.abe story OF IN, his s. iSv, S,
and minpling MS tale with weli-tlmsd nat
.. tery. induced NE to engage nm. Ah'
- carr;ape of Lady Caroline NJ was, a
y. .e This moment announced; presently At wa
. zone. @ and Henry departed. To gambling
. house in he proceeded; he was now ne
e. sv come come an adept in fashionable vice, AN
